Helen’s Hill Pinot Noir reviews

Written by
madeline
Posted in
reviews
Tagged
James Halliday, The Age, wine front, wine reviews

2015 vintage

James Halliday Wine Companion Review – October 2016

Star-bright crimson hue; two clones, both old, destemmed but not crushed for whole berry fermentation in open top fermenters with 8-10 days on skins. Pressed, settled and racked to French barriques for 11 months, held on fine lees without racking until racked for bottling. It has a highly aromatic bouquet with spicy plum aromas leading into a light to medium-bodied palate with savoury/foresty nuances providing a counterpoint to the plummy fruit. The balance and the length cannot be faulted in a wine that does full justice to a great vintage for pinot noir in the Yarra Valley. Its balance, and its screwcap (it is not the least reductive), will allow it to coast past 2025 for those who enjoy the full panoply of aromas and flavours of mature pinot noir. 96 points

2014 vintage

James Halliday Wine Companion Review – September 2015

The alcohol reading would suggest that it’s light, and in appearance it is. In the mouth though it has real get up and go, with herb and cherry-plum notes striking decisively towards a firm-but-long finish. Textbook shape; the aftertaste is the scene of the main action. 94 points

2013 vintage

James Halliday Wine Companion Review – April 2015

From clones MV6, 114 and 115, open-fermented with cultured (Burgundy) yeast. The colour is relatively light, but bright crimson; the latter the clue to the wine’s vibrant cherry fruit and its intensity; the bouquet evolves after 10 or 15 minutes to put the seal on the deal in no uncertain fashion, falling into step with the very long finish. 95 points

2012 vintage

James Halliday Wine Companion Review – January 2014 

The colour is even deeper than that of its Ingram Rd sibling; it is packed with luxurious dark cherry and plum fruit running in an unbroken stream through the bouquet, palate, finish and aftertaste. Exceptional pinot noir, and will hit the heights over the next 5+ years. 97 points

Wine Front 2013 review
“Dark cherries, musk, spice and vanilla wood – fetching sort of earthy minerality here too. Medium weight, plums and cherries, good acid cut and attack with fine but firm powdery tannin framing up the wine beautifully. Muscular and intense, but not without charm. Long finish. Ooomph and chutzpah. Carries it off with style. 93 points.”

2010 vintage

James Halliday 2011 review
“Strong, clear red-purple; estate-grown MV6, 113 and 114 clone grapes have come together in a top vintage to provide a pinot that has both depth and length to its display of dark plum and cherry fruit, French oak having its say, as do fine tannins – all in tune with each other. 94 points.”
The Age newspaper 2012 review
“A single-vineyard pinot from a strong vintage in the Yarra Valley with sweet, juicy fruit to the fore: dusty beetroot, black tea, stewed cherries. Warm in the mouth with a generous, fine tannin smoothness.”
